public void topoSortByKahn() {

â€‹ inDegree[k]â€“;

public void topoSortByDFS() {

private void dfs(

public void dijkstra(int s, int t) { // ä»é¡¶ç‚¹såˆ°é¡¶ç‚¹tçš„æœ€çŸ­è·¯å¾„

int[] predecessor = new int[this.v]; // ç”¨æ¥è¿˜åŸæœ€çŸ­è·¯å¾„

Vertex[] vertexes = new Vertex[this.v];

for (int i = 0; i < this.v; ++i) {

â€‹ vertexes[i] = new Vertex(i, Integer.MAX_VALUE);

}

PriorityQueue queue = new PriorityQueue(this.v);// å°é¡¶å †

boolean[] inqueue = new boolean[this.v]; // æ ‡è®°æ˜¯å¦è¿›å…¥è¿‡é˜Ÿåˆ—

vertexes[s].dist = 0;

queue.add(vertexes[s]);

inqueue[s] = true;

while (!queue.isEmpty()) {

â€‹ Vertex minVertex= queue.poll(); // å–å †é¡¶å…ƒç´ å¹¶åˆ é™¤

â€‹ if (minVertex.id == t) break; // æœ€çŸ­è·¯å¾„äº§ç”Ÿäº†

â€‹ for (int i = 0; i < adj[minVertex.id].size(); ++i) {

â€‹ Edge e = adj[minVertex.id].get(i); // å–å‡ºä¸€æ¡minVetexç›¸è¿çš„è¾¹

â€‹ Vertex nextVertex = vertexes[e.tid]; // minVertexâ€“>nextVertex

â€‹ if (minVertex.dist + e.w < nextVertex.dist) { // æ›´æ–°nextçš„dist

â€‹ nextVertex.dist = minVertex.dist + e.w;

â€‹ predecessor[nextVertex.id] = minVertex.id;

â€‹ if (inqueue[nextVertex.id] == true) {

â€‹ queue.update(nextVertex); // æ›´æ–°é˜Ÿåˆ—ä¸­çš„distå€¼

â€‹ } else {

â€‹ queue.add(nextVertex);

â€‹ inqueue[nextVertex.id] = true;

â€‹ }

â€‹ }

â€‹ }

}

// è¾“å‡ºæœ€çŸ­è·¯å¾„

System.out.print(s);

print(s, t, predecessor);

}

private void print(int s, int t, int[] predecessor) {

if (s == t) return;

print(s, predecessor[t], predecessor);

System.out.print(â€œ->â€ + t);

}

public class BitMap { // Javaä¸­charç±»å‹å 16bitï¼Œä¹Ÿå³æ˜¯2ä¸ªå­—èŠ‚

private char[] bytes;

private int nbits;

public BitMap(int nbits) {

â€‹ this.nbits = nbits;

â€‹ this.bytes = new char[nbits/16+1];

}

public void set(int k) {

â€‹ if (k > nbits) return;

â€‹ int byteIndex = k / 16;

â€‹ int bitIndex = k % 16;

â€‹ bytes[byteIndex] |= (1 << bitIndex);

}

public boolean get(int k) {

â€‹ if (k > nbits) return false;

â€‹ int byteIndex = k / 16;

â€‹ int bitIndex = k % 16;

â€‹ return (bytes[byteIndex] & (1 << bitIndex)) != 0;

}

}

è¿™é‡Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡è¿™ä¸ªé¡¶ç‚¹è·Ÿç»ˆç‚¹ä¹‹é—´çš„ç›´çº¿è·ç¦»ï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯æ¬§å‡ é‡Œå¾—è·ç¦»ï¼Œæ¥è¿‘ä¼¼åœ°ä¼°è®¡è¿™ä¸ªé¡¶ç‚¹è·Ÿç»ˆç‚¹çš„è·¯å¾„é•¿åº¦ï¼ˆæ³¨æ„ï¼šè·¯å¾„é•¿åº¦è·Ÿç›´çº¿è·ç¦»æ˜¯ä¸¤ä¸ªæ¦‚å¿µï¼‰ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬æŠŠè¿™ä¸ªè·ç¦»è®°ä½œ h(i)ï¼ˆi è¡¨ç¤ºè¿™ä¸ªé¡¶ç‚¹çš„ç¼–å·ï¼‰ï¼Œä¸“ä¸šçš„å«æ³•æ˜¯å¯å‘å‡½æ•°ï¼ˆheuristic functionï¼‰ã€‚å› ä¸ºæ¬§å‡ é‡Œå¾—è·ç¦»çš„è®¡ç®—å…¬å¼ï¼Œä¼šæ¶‰åŠæ¯”è¾ƒè€—æ—¶çš„å¼€æ ¹å·è®¡ç®—ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸€èˆ¬é€šè¿‡å¦å¤–ä¸€ä¸ªæ›´åŠ ç®€å•çš„è·ç¦»è®¡ç®—å…¬å¼ï¼Œé‚£å°±æ˜¯æ›¼å“ˆé¡¿è·ç¦»ï¼ˆManhattan distanceï¼‰ã€‚æ›¼å“ˆé¡¿è·ç¦»æ˜¯ä¸¤ç‚¹ä¹‹é—´æ¨ªçºµåæ ‡çš„è·ç¦»ä¹‹å’Œã€‚è®¡ç®—çš„è¿‡ç¨‹åªæ¶‰åŠåŠ å‡æ³•ã€ç¬¦å·ä½åè½¬ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æ¯”æ¬§å‡ é‡Œå¾—è·ç¦»æ›´åŠ é«˜æ•ˆã€‚

int hManhattan(Vertex v1, Vertex v2) { // Vertexè¡¨ç¤ºé¡¶ç‚¹ï¼Œåé¢æœ‰å®šä¹‰

return Math.abs(v1.x - v2.x) + Math.abs(v1.y - v2.y);

private class Vertex {

public Vertex(int id, int x, int y) {

â€‹ this.id = id;

â€‹ this.f = Integer.MAX_VALUE;

â€‹ this.dist = Integer.MAX_VALUE;

// Graphç±»çš„æˆå‘˜å˜é‡ï¼Œåœ¨æ„é€ å‡½æ•°ä¸­åˆå§‹åŒ–

Vertex[] vertexes = new Vertex[this.v];

public void addVetex(int id, int x, int y) {

ä¼˜å…ˆçº§é˜Ÿåˆ—æ„å»ºçš„æ–¹å¼ä¸åŒã€‚A* ç®—æ³•æ˜¯æ ¹æ® f å€¼ï¼ˆä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯åˆšåˆšè®²åˆ°çš„ f(i)=g(i)+h(i)ï¼‰æ¥æ„å»ºä¼˜å…ˆçº§é˜Ÿåˆ—ï¼Œè€Œ Dijkstra ç®—æ³•æ˜¯æ ¹æ® dist å€¼ï¼ˆä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯åˆšåˆšè®²åˆ°çš„ g(i)ï¼‰æ¥æ„å»ºä¼˜å…ˆçº§é˜Ÿåˆ—ï¼›

å¾ªç¯ç»“æŸçš„æ¡ä»¶ä¹Ÿä¸ä¸€æ ·ã€‚Dijkstra ç®—æ³•æ˜¯åœ¨ç»ˆç‚¹å‡ºé˜Ÿåˆ—çš„æ—¶å€™æ‰ç»“æŸï¼ŒA* ç®—æ³•æ˜¯ä¸€æ—¦éå†åˆ°ç»ˆç‚¹å°±ç»“æŸã€‚

public void astar(int s, int t) { // ä»é¡¶ç‚¹såˆ°é¡¶ç‚¹tçš„è·¯å¾„

int[] predecessor = new int[this.v]; // ç”¨æ¥è¿˜åŸè·¯å¾„

// æŒ‰ç…§vertexçš„få€¼æ„å»ºçš„å°é¡¶å †ï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯æŒ‰ç…§dist

PriorityQueue queue = new PriorityQueue(this.v);

boolean[] inqueue = new boolean[this.v]; // æ ‡è®°æ˜¯å¦è¿›å…¥è¿‡é˜Ÿåˆ—

vertexes[s].dist = 0;

vertexes[s].f = 0;

queue.add(vertexes[s]);

inqueue[s] = true;

while (!queue.isEmpty()) {

â€‹ Vertex minVertex = queue.poll(); // å–å †é¡¶å…ƒç´ å¹¶åˆ é™¤

â€‹ for (int i = 0; i < adj[minVertex.id].size(); ++i) {

â€‹ Edge e = adj[minVertex.id].get(i); // å–å‡ºä¸€æ¡minVetexç›¸è¿çš„è¾¹

â€‹ Vertex nextVertex = vertexes[e.tid]; // minVertexâ€“>nextVertex

â€‹ if (minVertex.dist + e.w < nextVertex.dist) { // æ›´æ–°nextçš„dist,f

â€‹ nextVertex.dist = minVertex.dist + e.w;

â€‹ nextVertex.f

â€‹ = nextVertex.dist+hManhattan(nextVertex, vertexes[t]);

â€‹ predecessor[nextVertex.id] = minVertex.id;

â€‹ if (inqueue[nextVertex.id] == true) {

â€‹ queue.update(nextVertex);

â€‹ } else {

â€‹ queue.add(nextVertex);

â€‹ inqueue[nextVertex.id] = true;

â€‹ }

â€‹ }

â€‹ if (nextVertex.id == t) { // åªè¦åˆ°è¾¾tå°±å¯ä»¥ç»“æŸwhileäº†

â€‹ queue.clear(); // æ¸…ç©ºqueueï¼Œæ‰èƒ½æ¨å‡ºwhileå¾ªç¯

â€‹ break;

â€‹ }

â€‹ }

}

// è¾“å‡ºè·¯å¾„

System.out.print(s);

print(s, t, predecessor); // printå‡½æ•°è¯·å‚çœ‹Dijkstraç®—æ³•çš„å®ç°

}

public class Queue {

private Long[] data;

private int size = 0, head = 0, tail = 0;

public Queue(int size) {

â€‹ this.data = new Long[size];

â€‹ this.size = size;

}

public boolean add(Long element) {

â€‹ if ((tail + 1) % size == head) return false;

â€‹ data[tail] = element;

â€‹ tail = (tail + 1) % size;

â€‹ return true;

}

public Long poll() {

â€‹ if (head == tail) return null;

â€‹ long ret = data[head];

â€‹ head = (head + 1) % size;

â€‹ return ret;

}

}

public class Producer {

private Queue queue;

public Producer(Queue queue) {

â€‹ this.queue = queue;

}

public void produce(Long data) throws InterruptedException {

â€‹ while (!queue.add(data)) {

â€‹ Thread.sleep(100);

â€‹ }

}

}

â€‹ if (data == null) {

}

æˆ‘ä»¬è¿ç”¨ç¬¬ä¸€æ€§åŸç†ï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯æ¯”è¾ƒæ€ç»´å»æ€è€ƒé—®é¢˜æ˜¯éå¸¸é‡è¦çš„ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ç”Ÿæ´»ä¸­æ€»æ˜¯å€¾å‘äºæ¯”è¾ƒï¼Œå¯¹åˆ«äººå·²ç»åšè¿‡æˆ–è€…æ­£åœ¨åšçš„äº‹æƒ…æˆ‘ä»¬ä¹Ÿéƒ½å»åšï¼Œè¿™æ ·å‘å±•çš„ç»“æœåªèƒ½äº§ç”Ÿç»†å°çš„è¿­ä»£å‘å±•ã€‚

ç¬¬ä¸€æ€§åŸç†çš„æ€æƒ³æ–¹å¼æ˜¯ç”¨ç‰©ç†å­¦çš„è§’åº¦çœ‹å¾…ä¸–ç•Œï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯è¯´ä¸€å±‚å±‚æ‹¨å¼€äº‹ç‰©è¡¨è±¡ï¼Œçœ‹åˆ°é‡Œé¢çš„æœ¬è´¨ï¼Œå†ä»æœ¬è´¨ä¸€å±‚å±‚å¾€ä¸Šèµ°ã€‚

i mean first principles thinking is just saying what are the most fundamental truths that we know about any given situation like the things that at a very granular(é¢—ç²’çš„) level, the most the sort of simplest building blocks that we are most convinced are true and then you reason up from those fundamental axioms.

First principles thinking is the act of boiling a process down to the fundamental parts that you know are true and building up from there.

This is the process of first principles thinking in a nutshell. It is a cycle of breaking a situation down into the core pieces and then putting them all back together in a more effective way. Deconstruct then reconstruct.ã€é€’å½’ï¼ã€‘

The snowmobile example also highlights another hallmark of first principles thinking, which is the combination of ideas from seemingly unrelated fields. A tank and a bicycle appear to have nothing in common, but pieces of a tank and a bicycle can be combined to develop innovations like a snowmobile.[ç»è¿‡æ‹†è§£åï¼Œå¯ä»¥ç»„åˆconnect æˆæ–°çš„ä¸œè¥¿ã€‚æ‹†çš„é¢—ç²’å°ï¼Œæ‰èƒ½å‘ç°å…±æ€§çš„ä¸œè¥¿]

The best solution is not where everyone is already looking.

First principles thinking helps you to cobble together information from different disciplines to create new ideas and innovations. You start by getting to the facts. Once you have a foundation of facts, you can make a plan to improve each little piece. This process naturally leads to exploring widely for better substitutes.

What looks like innovation is often an iteration of previous forms rather than an improvement of the core function. While everyone else was focused on how to build a better bag (form), Sadow considered how to store and move things more efficiently (function).

Optimize the function. Ignore the form. This is how you learn to think for yourself.

First principles thinking does not remove the need for continuous improvement, but it does alter the direction of improvement. Without reasoning by first principles, you spend your time making small improvements to a bicycle rather than a snowmobile. First principles thinking sets you on a different trajectory.ã€ç¬¬ä¸€åŸç†æ€è€ƒæä¾›æ–¹å‘æŒ‡å¼•ã€‘

If you want to enhance an existing process or belief, continuous improvement is a great option. If you want to learn how to think for yourself, reasoning from first principles is one of the best ways to do it.

Effectively, Word2Vec is based on distributional hypothesis where the context for each word is in its nearby words. Hence, by looking at its neighbouring words, we can attempt to predict the target word.

Here is a slightly more general definition:

[Machine Learning is the] field of study that gives computers the ability to learn without being explicitly programmed.

And a more engineering-oriented one:

A computer program is said to learn from experience E with respect to some task T and some performance measure P, if its performance on T, as measured by P, improves with experience E.

In order to generalize well, it is crucial that your training data be representative of the new cases you want to generalize to. This is true whether you use instance-based learning or model-based learning.

ä¸ºäº†æ³›åŒ–èƒ½åŠ›å¼ºï¼Œå…³é”®çš„æ˜¯ä½ çš„è®­ç»ƒé›†è¦èƒ½å¤Ÿä»£è¡¨æˆ–è¡¨ç¤ºä½ æƒ³è¦é¢„æµ‹çš„æ–°case.

It is crucial to use a training set that is representative of the cases you want to generalâ€ ize to. This is often harder than it sounds: if the sample is too small, you will have sampling noise (i.e., nonrepresentative data as a result of chance), but even very large samples can be nonrepresentative if the sampling method is flawed. This is called sampling bias.

the validation set and the test must be as representative as possible of the data you expect to use in production

éªŒè¯é›†å’Œæµ‹è¯•é›†å¿…é¡»è¦è·Ÿæˆ‘ä»¬ç”Ÿäº§ç¯å¢ƒå°†è¦é¢ä¸´çš„æ•°æ®ä¿æŒä¸€ç›´ï¼ï¼

  • è®­ç»ƒéœ€è¦çš„æ ·æœ¬é‡

As of 2016, a rough rule of thumb is that a supervised deep learning algorithm will generally achieve acceptable performance with around 5,000 labeled examples per category, and will match or exceed human performance when trained with a dataset containing at least 10 million labeled examples. Working successfully with datasets smaller than this is an important research area, focusing in particular on how we can take advantage of large quantities of unlabeled examples, with unsupervised or semi-supervised learning.

å¯¹äºç›‘ç£æ·±åº¦å­¦ä¹ ç®—æ³•ï¼Œæ¯ç±»çš„æ ·æœ¬æ ‡æ³¨é‡ 5000ï¼Œé€šå¸¸å¯ä»¥è¾¾åˆ°å¯æ¥å—çš„æ€§èƒ½ï¼›è€Œåœ¨ä½¿ç”¨åŒ…å«è‡³å°‘1000ä¸‡ä¸ªå¸¦æ ‡ç­¾ç¤ºä¾‹çš„æ•°æ®é›†è¿›è¡Œè®­ç»ƒæ—¶ï¼Œå®ƒå°†è¾¾åˆ°æˆ–è¶…è¿‡äººç±»çš„æ€§èƒ½

  • æµ‹è¯•é›†åˆ’åˆ†æ¯”ä¾‹

It is common to use 80% of the data for training and hold out 20% for testing. However, this depends on the size of the dataset: if it contains 10 million instances, then holding out 1% means your test set will contain 100,000 instances: thatâ€™s probably more than enough to get a good estimate of the generalization error.

ä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯è¯´ï¼Œå¦‚æœæ ·æœ¬æ•°é‡å¾ˆå¤šï¼Œåˆ™ä¸å¿…2-8åˆ’åˆ†ã€‚

  • äº¤å‰éªŒè¯

äº¤å‰éªŒè¯ä¸»è¦æ˜¯è¯´åœ¨æ ·æœ¬é›†å°‘çš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æ—¢æƒ³ç”¨è¶³å¤Ÿå¤šçš„è®­ç»ƒé›†å»è®­ç»ƒæ•°æ®ï¼Œåˆæƒ³å¾—åˆ°è¶…å‚æ•°çš„åˆé€‚é€‰æ‹©ã€‚

è¿™æ—¶å€™å¯ä»¥é‡‡ç”¨äº¤å‰éªŒè¯ï¼Œå¹¶ç”¨å¤šæ¬¡çš„å¹³å‡å»åšè¯„ä¼°ï¼Œè¿™æ ·ç»“è®ºä¼šæ›´å‡†ç¡®

æ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œäº¤å‰éªŒè¯ç›®çš„æ˜¯å¯¹è¶…å‚æ•°çš„åšä¸€ä¸ªæ›´ä¼˜çš„é€‰æ‹©ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯ä»£ä»·æ˜¯è®­ç»ƒæ—¶é—´å‘¨æœŸé•¿

A common solution to this problem is called holdout validation: you simply hold out part of the training set to evaluate several candidate models and select the best one. The new heldout set is called the validation set (or sometimes the development set, or dev set). More specifically, you train multiple models with various hyperparameters on the reduced training set (i.e., the full training set minus the validation set), and you select the model that performs best on the validation set. After this holdout valiâ€ dation process, you train the best model on the full training set (including the validaâ€ tion set), and this gives you the final model. Lastly, you evaluate this final model on the test set to get an estimate of the generalization error.

This solution usually works quite well. However, if the validation set is too small, then model evaluations will be imprecise: you may end up selecting a suboptimal model by mistake. Conversely, if the validation set is too large, then the remaining training set will be much smaller than the full training set. Why is this bad? Well, since the final model will be trained on the full training set, it is not ideal to compare candidate models trained on a much smaller training set. It would be like selecting the fastest sprinter to participate in a marathon. One way to solve this problem is to perform repeated cross-validation, using many small validation sets. Each model is evaluated once per validation set, after it is trained on the rest of the data. By averaging out all the evaluations of a model, we get a much more accurate measure of its performance. However, there is a drawback: the training time is multiplied by the number of validaâ€ tion sets.â€”-ã€4ã€‘p32

The upper 4 bit is called the OPR and contains the operation code. The lower 4 bits is called OPA and contains the modifier. For a single word machine instruction the operation code (OPR) contains the code of the operation that is to be performed (add, subtract, load, etc.). The modifie (OPA) contains one of 4 things:

1.A register address
2.A register pair address
3.4 bits of data
4.An instruction modifier
